1.text: I made a covenant with mine eyes; why then should I think upon a maid?

2.text: For what portion of God [is there] from above? and [what] inheritance of the Almighty from on high?

3.text: [Is] not destruction to the wicked? and a strange [punishment] to the workers of iniquity?

4.text: Doth not he see my ways, and count all my steps?

5.text: If I have walked with vanity, or if my foot hath hasted to deceit;

6.text: Let me be weighed in an even balance, that God may know mine integrity.

7.text: If my step hath turned out of the way, and mine heart walked after mine eyes, and if any blot hath cleaved to mine hands;

8.text: [Then] let me sow, and let another eat; yea, let my offspring be rooted out.

9.text: If mine heart have been deceived by a woman, or [if] I have laid wait at my neighbour’s door;

10.text: [Then] let my wife grind unto another, and let others bow down upon her.

11.text: For this [is] an heinous crime; yea, it [is] an iniquity [to be punished by] the judges.

12.text: For it [is] a fire [that] consumeth to destruction, and would root out all mine increase.

13.text: If I did despise the cause of my manservant or of my maidservant, when they contended with me;

14.text: What then shall I do when God riseth up? and when he visiteth, what shall I answer him?

15.text: Did not he that made me in the womb make him? and did not one fashion us in the womb?

16.text: If I have withheld the poor from [their] desire, or have caused the eyes of the widow to fail;

17.text: Or have eaten my morsel myself alone, and the fatherless hath not eaten thereof;

18.text: (For from my youth he was brought up with me, as [with] a father, and I have guided her from my mother’s womb;)

19.text: If I have seen any perish for want of clothing, or any poor without covering;

20.text: If his loins have not blessed me, and [if] he were [not] warmed with the fleece of my sheep;

21.text: If I have lifted up my hand against the fatherless, when I saw my help in the gate:

22.text: [Then] let mine arm fall from my shoulder blade, and mine arm be broken from the bone.

23.text: For destruction [from] God [was] a terror to me, and by reason of his highness I could not endure.

24.text: If I have made gold my hope, or have said to the fine gold, [Thou art] my confidence;

25.text: If I rejoiced because my wealth [was] great, and because mine hand had gotten much;

26.text: If I beheld the sun when it shined, or the moon walking [in] brightness;

27.text: And my heart hath been secretly enticed, or my mouth hath kissed my hand:

28.text: This also [were] an iniquity [to be punished by] the judge: for I should have denied the God [that is] above.

29.text: If I rejoiced at the destruction of him that hated me, or lifted up myself when evil found him:

30.text: Neither have I suffered my mouth to sin by wishing a curse to his soul.

31.text: If the men of my tabernacle said not, Oh that we had of his flesh! we cannot be satisfied.

32.text: The stranger did not lodge in the street: [but] I opened my doors to the traveller.

33.text: If I covered my transgressions as Adam, by hiding mine iniquity in my bosom:

34.text: Did I fear a great multitude, or did the contempt of families terrify me, that I kept silence, [and] went not out of the door?

35.text: Oh that one would hear me! behold, my desire [is, that] the Almighty would answer me, and [that] mine adversary had written a book.

36.text: Surely I would take it upon my shoulder, [and] bind it [as] a crown to me.

37.text: I would declare unto him the number of my steps; as a prince would I go near unto him.

38.text: If my land cry against me, or that the furrows likewise thereof complain;

39.text: If I have eaten the fruits thereof without money, or have caused the owners thereof to lose their life:

40.text: Let thistles grow instead of wheat, and cockle instead of barley. The words of Job are ended.
